author: Chris Kitching for MailOnline
title: Passengers caught with guns in their hand luggage at airports can avoid a charge if they FORGOT they'd packed them
text:
View
comments
Travellers who are caught with a handgun in their carry-on luggage at airports in Texas can now escape charges under a new state law.
Starting this week passengers who have a licence to carry a concealed handgun can avoid arrest as long as they leave the security checkpoint when the firearm is found in their bag or purse.
The new legislation means that a passenger can blame a poor memory for the transgression.

Transportation Security Administration (TSA) officers find dozens of guns every week at airports across the US and many of the offenders claim they simply forgot the firearm was in their possession at the time.
In 2014, the TSA discovered a record 2,212 firearms at US airports, with the most discoveries taking place airports in southern states, including Dallas/Fort Worth in Texas (120) and Hartsfield-Jackson in Atlanta, Georgia (109).
Including Dallas/Fort Worth, three Texas airports ranked in the top six. Houston’s George Bush Intercontinental Airport ranked fourth with 77 guns seized, while the city’s other airport, William P Hobby, was sixth with 50 seizures.

Over the last week of August, 48 firearms were found at TSA checkpoints – 42 were loaded and 15 had a round chambered, the agency said on its blog, which provides weekly updates and photos of weapons seized from travellers.
The discoveries often lead to delays at checkpoints.
But the number of seizures at Texas airports is just a drop in the bucket compared to the number of firearms in the state.
This gun was seized at Houston's William P Hobby Airport, where some of the most discoveries take place
According to the Dallas Morning News , there are more than 870,000 handgun licence holders in the state.
Despite the state law, the TSA can still hand out a civil penalty for bringing a firearm into a security checkpoint, with a fine of up to $7,500 (£4,900) for a loaded gun, the newspaper reported.
In response to the legislation, Sen. Juan ‘Chuy’ Hinojosa, a licence holder who had charges dismissed after a handgun was found in his briefcase at Texas airport in 2005, told the Dallas Morning News: ‘It provides discretion to law enforcement to make a judgment right then and there. Was it just an unintentional mistake?’
In the US, passengers can travel with firearms in their checked baggage, but they must first be declared to the airline, with laws varying by state and municipality.
Ammunition can be placed in a checked bag, but it is not allowed in hand luggage.
